captions.text:
-Well, for those of you who are
still here, we want to let

you know that we read your
comments, we've heard what you
had to say.

And because of that, we're
going to give you
a lot more of this.
Bob?
Stay tuned.

In 1967, Chevrolet released the
Camaro as the answer to
Ford's Mustang.

It looked great, sold by the
thousands, and came with no

fewer than five engine
choices.

In the realm of muscle cars, the
Camaro is one of the most
popular rides.

It's got a fan base that's
really unparalleled.

Therefore, it's no surprise that
Bob Hall chose the Camaro

as the car that he
always wanted.

He's been wanting one since
he's been like 18.

But he had to wait
till his family
obligations were filled.

-This car was always a car
that I desired to have.

I wanted a convertible
Camaro from the '60s

Any of them would have
done it for me.

I mean I just love that first
generation convertible.

So why did I decide to build a
pro touring Camaro versus a
restoration?

That is a good question, but I
started off, I was going to
restore the vehicle.

And as I got more involved and
started going to the car

shows, I saw these pro touring
Camaros out there.

And based on my rebel
background, I guess, I just
decided that's me.

I'm not going to be comfortable
sitting behind a

restored Camaro in
a lawn chair.

And therefore, that started
the journey.

-What you see here is a
representation of Bob's
perfect Camaro.

Obviously, things have
been modified.

It has the LSA engine out
of a CTS-V Cadillac.

The suspension has been done
from front to rear.

And from a performance
standpoint, the car is simply
unbelievable.

Today, we're very fortunate,
because right now, I'm sitting

behind the wheel of Bob Hall's
1968 Camaro convertible.
It's an SS model.

Now, this is not your average
Camaro convertible.

You see this car has a couple
of little bells and whistles

into it one of which is the
800-horsepower LSA engine that

was sourced from a
wrecked CTS-V.

To the wheels, it makes
648 horsepower and 650
pound-feet of torque.

I mean, this car has more power
at the rear wheels, than
a ZR1 Corvette make stock.
Unreal.

We're rolling right now not that
fast, maybe at about 40
or so miles an hour.

It is unbelievably docile,
there are no squeaks and

rattles, and there is nothing in
this car that would let you

know that it is the epitome of
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.
It's a gorgeous day.
We're tooling around.

Kind of playing with the
car a little bit,
rolling through the gears.

It's when you open the taps on
this car when you really hear
things happen.

This is a carnival ride
of an automobile.

It makes you giggle and
it makes you smile.

-The motor is absolutely
stock.

I went one size smaller on the
supercharger pulley, which

brought it from around 7 pounds
of boost to now roughly
10 pounds of boost.

And then the inside of the
supercharger was all cast, so

we smoothed that out
and polished it.

And I put a spacer in
to help with cooling
on the inner cooler.

Other than that, the motor
is absolutely stock.

-When you think about cars like
the new Camaro ZL1 that

are coming out, which is
essentially powered by the

same exact engine, you've got
a wonder if Bob was really,
really ahead of the curve.

There is no way I would
take that over this.
Never happened.

This car has got the
personality.

It's got the looks, and Bob has
managed to maintain the

feel of that old-school
personality in this car.

That's something that's
so tough to do.
Listen to that.
It handles.

The six-piston band breaks
will stop you on a dime.

The T-56 transmission,
beautiful.

70, 80 miles an hour you're
cruising at 2500 RPMs without
a care in the world.

That's what people have to
understand about this car.
These little roll ons like--
that's like [INAUDIBLE].

If I were to put my foot down on
these things, we'd spin the

tires for like an eighth
of a mile.

The issue with that is, well
one, it's not my car and two,

this car has Michelin mileage
work-ups on it.

Those are like five bills,
five bills a side.
That's a lot of bread.
Not my bread, his bread.

-Currently, I'm running 275, 35,
18s on the back, which are
about a 10.9 inch width wheel.

And then I'm running 235,
40, 18s on the front.

I've ran into several
people that
underestimated this car so far.

Some on the freeway, most recent
on my way back from the

Del Mar Show, the Good Guy Show
in Del Mar, I ran into a

brand new Ferrari, he and his
girlfriend/wife in the car.

Apparently, he underestimated
the car, because he thought he

was going to show this old '68
what the heck a new car does,

and he eventually
caught up to me.

-Now, it took Bob three years
to build this thing.
He started back in 2009.

He built this as not only his
dream car, but something that

he could just enjoy with his
wife and his grandkids.

Man, this guy is definitely the
coolest grandfather I've
ever met.
-I have three granddaughters.

The two older ones I can't let
them in the garage without
them climbing in my Camaro.

And then they cry when I
try to take them out.
-That cracks me up.

Can you see him in the
back with his three
granddaughters back here?

Probably giggling
all day long.
He also wanted to play.

What I mean by that is, he'll
take this to the Autocross and
beat it to death.

That's one of the beauties of
this thing, is because of its
bone reliable.
90 degrees out right now.
Temper gauge hasn't moved.

It gets 18.8 miles to the gallon
on the highway with no
problem whatsoever.

And it makes the most glorious
sounds you could think of.
It's nothing but fun, man.

As you can see, Bob spent
a lot of time on the
exterior of the car.

The paint scheme, the wheels,
everything flows.

And that continues into the
interior of the car as well.

Beautiful Recaro seats, carbon
fiber dash and center console

help the car have this wonderful
tie-in feel.

Everything flows and works
in conjunction.

The entire dashboard is redone,
and yet, he's kept so

many of the things that's made
this stock car great to keep

that wonderful, classic
look and feel.

The gauge panel, for instance,
is done in carbon fiber.

And yet he's kept the original
gauges behind the panel.

The center console is done
in carbon fiber as well.

The steering wheel is a built-in
specialties unit that
just helps tie everything in.

It's a whole package,
this car.

And you have to remember that
when you're building a car
like this, there's no formula.

You don't just go to the
dictionary and look up '68

Camaro, and all of a sudden,
this thing pops up.

You have to sit down, and
you have to think.

You have to research and do
your due diligence on the

parts that you want
these things to
make it a full package.

90% of the cars out there,
especially the pro touring

ones, I'm not going to say
they're hacked up, but they

damn well don't drive nearly
as good as this thing.
-Is the car done?

I don't think these cars
are ever done.

There's several things like
I really want to still do.

One is obviously put some
more meat on the ground.
It's an undertaking.

It isn't just buying
rims and tires.

It's going to take some
sheet metal work.

I've tried to leave the car in
a condition that I could

always restore it back
to how I started.

Again, I think that's why I've
always respected the car by

everything I've done has been
and tasteful and carefully
thought out.
It's always a struggle.

I mean you obviously
want to preserve
that and go that direction.

But I just have this fire
that tells me you got a
rock and roll, Bob.

You're not getting
any younger.
You better enjoy it now.

-Today, we came out with Bob
Hall and his ridiculous 1968

Camaro, one of the best pro
touring cars I've ever driven.

So Bob, I can't thank
you enough for
bringing this thing out.
Anybody you want to talk to?

Anybody you want to thank
for this thing?

Aside for yourself for
paying for it.
-Well, definitely.

I think there are some people
who deserve credit for

building my dream car and
that's Rob Phillips of

Phillips and Company Hot Rod,
Aaron at Orange County Hot

Rods, and Carl Casanova for
helping me set up a fuel

system that communicates with
this motor, and Hodgkiss for

their support in get
me started on
this pro touring kick.

-Well, I'll tell you, you've got
one hell of a car on your
hands, man.

And thanks for letting
us drive it.
-No problem.
-We appreciate it.
-Thanks.

-Guys, stay tuned for more
Big Muscle on Drive, and
we'll see you soon.
Really?
Eight miles an hour?

I didn't even know that
was possible.
Seriously.

We got stuck behind the slowest
guy in the history of
southern California.

Like you have to really have
to try to go that slow.
Yeah, it's pretty accurate.

He's actually going
slower than 15.
Oh, my God.
I cannot believe that slow.

800 horsepower and
15 miles an hour.
That's so painful.

title: CTS-V Powered '68 Camaro Drop Top - /BIG MUSCLE

you call yourself a car Enthusiast but you are not you only like one type

comments.author: mintkendishin

comments.text:
Here's a tip, don't go full throttle out of a corner in a vette. Auto-X is 
low speed racing in parking lots. Take it to a real track and watch what 
happens. Perfect power-weight ratio sounds like anemic engine qualities but 
handles decently enough to make up for that short coming.
comments.author: zzDarkwingDuck

comments.text:
Your grammar is getting worse. Plus, you blatant lack of automotive 
mechanics is still glaring. Mustangs, Camaro's, Vettes, Vipers all weigh 
less than a Supra or GTR. They also make more power, so unless you're 
completely inept at math, you can see why your power-to-weight ratio 
argument is useless. A Pontiac Fiero is a better match for a 90's Miata.
comments.author: The Random Page

comments.text:
alot of understeer and if I gave it fullthrottle out of thecorners i would 
just spin outwhen it comes to autocross a light weight balanced car seem to 
perform better simply because of all the corners they would set up at this 
particular autocrossevent.now if there was long straights it would be a 
different story the vette for sure would get better timesI have 
noexperience with modern american cars but im sure they perform alot better 
some jap cars have perfect power to weight ratio in stock form
comments.author: mintkendishin

comments.text:
I have no knowledge about ls motors....... I know a lil bit about the 1uzfe 
which i converted to 5sd trans using the r154 tranny on a lexus sc400 but i 
couldnt figure out the wiring :/.......... ive driven a lotus elise on auto 
cross and my friends early 90s vette on the autocross.... what i noticed 
was that i did lil to no breaking in the lotus and i was right back on the 
throttle coming out of each corner....... but with the vette i would have 
to break hard into each corner and i was getting
comments.author: mintkendishin

comments.text:
I thought you may be a tragically misled car enthusiast, but no, you're 
just a ricer. Along with being a ricer, you have zero legitimate auto 
knowledge. 1st, LS series motors drop into first gen Camaro's without a 
hitch. 2nd I have no doubt that a modified miata can be a stock corvette, 
you can find a video of anything beating anything, it doesn't prove 
anything if you don't compare model years, price, or modifications. Ricers 
need more money and more mods to even keep up with american cars.
comments.author: The Random Page

comments.text:
Great video. Only problem I have with it is you state it runs 650 to the 
wheels. The owner states the motor is stock with exception of smaller 
pulley running 10psi boost.. the lsa engine out of a ctsv running 10psi and 
a tune will not net you anywhere near 650whp. Try about 550whp. Still good 
numbers without a doubt but incorrect figures none the less.
comments.author: robert morffi

comments.text:
Yea this isnt a normal camaro. this is like camaro with like a 
$50000conversionAre you kiddding me!.theres evos with world track records 
at this very moment.Ive seen lightly motified miatas get better times then 
a corvette at autocross meets Its all about the power to weight ratio when 
it comes to autocross because its non stop corners when you come out of a 
tight corner you cant just stomp on the gas with a vette because you will 
just break loose every time not the same with a well balanced car
comments.author: mintkendishin

comments.text: :D

comments.text:

up against in autocross. Nothing Japanese can outhandle Corvettes, Vipers, 
or even Cobra Mustangs.
